info.title: API documentation
info.description:
Welcome to the API documentation.
# Introduction
The service API is a RESTful API. You interact with the service via the API by sending HTTP requests.
All features available in the graphical user interface are also available via the API.
\
\
The documentation will first show you the information about managing users and creating API tokens, which are necessary
to get started using the API.
You will then learn how to manage projects and servers.

get.description: Shows information (email, ID, a number of servers, and so on) about your account.
Returns a list of your notifications.

delete.description: Deletes your notifications.

get.description: Returns a list of all your SSH keys.

post.description: Adds a new SSH key when you send the corresponding public key in the request body.

get.description: Returns a list of your API tokens (name and ID).

post.description: Creates a new API token.

get.description: Returns a list of all activity logs.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: Page number. The response is paginated with 50 items per page.

get.description: Returns a list of all API tokens (name and user).

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: Page number. The response is paginated with 50 items per page.

post.description: Creates a new User API token.

get.description: Shows information about the API token with the specified ID.

delete.description: Deletes an API token whose ID you provide.

patch.description:
Updates the API token with the specified ID.
     The request body attributes you want to update must be specified.

get.description: Returns a list of available applications.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: Page number. The response is paginated with 50 items per page.

post.description: Creates an Application.

delete.description: Deletes multiple Applications.

get.description: Shows information about an Application whose ID you provide.

put.description: Updates an Application whose ID you provide. You must send all the request body attributes.

delete.description: Deletes an Application whose ID you provide.

patch.description:
Updates an Application whose ID you provide. You must send those request body attributes that
     you want to update.

post.description: Registers a new user with the email and password you send.

Sends an email with a password verification link to a user whose ID you provide.
     The user must be already registered with the service. The verification link is valid for 25 hours since the user's
     registration.
Creates an API token when you send the login and password of a registered user.

Terminates the existing API token. The token becomes invalid and can no longer be used to make
     API requests.

put.summary: Reset a Password by a Token
put.description: Resets your password when you provide your token.

post.description:
Sends an email with a password reset link. You can send this API request every 60 seconds and a
     sent link is valid for 24 hours since the API request.

get.description: Do nothing except verify the token.

post.description: Confirm identity.

get.summary: Retrieve the Secret and QR code
get.description: Returns the secret and QR code for authenticator application.

post.description: Enables two-factor authentication.

delete.description: Disables two-factor authentication.

post.description: Generates new two-factor authentication recovery codes.
Creates an API token when you send the code from authenticator application.

The URL of the VNC proxy server
                                that handles the decryption and redirects to the provided URL.

get.description: Returns a list of all servers.

parameters.name: page
parameters.description: Page number. The response is paginated with 50 items per page by default.

post.description:
It is a quick way of creating a server compared with the *Create a Server Under a Project* API
     request. You only need to provide a server name while other settings (a compute resource, a plan, an OS, and so on)
     are optional. If you do not submit them, our service will create a server with the default settings defined by the
     administrator.\
     **Note:** If the administrator did not define the default settings, the API request will fail.
     In this case, use the *Create a Server Under a Project* API request to create a server.

delete.summary: Free up IP Address or delete from block
delete.description:
Frees up a reserved IP address. The IP address will be again available to be assigned to a newly
    created server. It's also used to delete IP address from block with `set` list type.
    It's also possible to use this method to delete additional IP addresses from a virtual server
    (Deprecated, use `DELETE /servers/{serverId}/ips/{ipId}` for deleting additional IPs).

patch.description:
Patches an IP (a reservation flag for an IP from an IP block with SET list type)
whose ID you provide.

delete.summary: Free up multiple IP Addresses or delete from block
delete.description:
Frees up multiple IP addresses. The IP addresses will be again available to be assigned to newly
     created servers. It's also used to delete IP addresses from block with `set` list type.

post.description: Creates a new project.

Adds you to project members. To send this API request, you need to have an email invitation sent
     you by the project owner.

Removes you from the list of project members. The project will disappear from your user
     interface. You will no longer be able to create, delete, and manage servers under the project.

get.description: Shows information about a project token pricing whose ID you provide.
Returns a list of existing project members under a particular project.

post.description:
Sends an email with a project invitation link to a user.
    The user will then follow the link and join the project.
    If the user is not registered with the service, they will receive an email with the registration form.
    Once they register, they will be already a project member.

delete.description:
Removes a user from the list of project members. The user will no longer see the project in
     their user interface. The user will no longer be able to create, delete, and manage servers under the
     project.

post.description: Resends an email with a project invitation link to a project member.

post.description:
Creates a new server with the desired settings under a particular project. The settings (a
     compute resource, a plan, an OS, and so on) are mandatory.\
     **Note:** To create a server faster and with the default settings, use the *Create a Server(Quick)* API request.
Create reverse dns.

password.description: User password, MUST contain a mix of upper and lower case letters, as well as digits

language_id.description: The ID of the interface language.

type.description: A type of the application login link.

content.description:
Login link content. Valid values depend on the selected link type.
You can use a variable for generating content the same way as for user_data_template.

 * For the `url` link type, use a valid URL address.
 * For the `js-code` link type, use a valid JS script. The script must meet the following requirements:
    - The script’s maximum execution time is 30 seconds.
    - You can use only the following JS functions and objects in the script
        * console
        * Math
        * parseInt
        * parseFloat
        * Object
        * JSON
        * encodeURI
        * encodeURIComponent
        * decodeURI
        * decodeURIComponent
        * atob
        * btoa
        * fetch
        * openWindow (acts the same way as `window.open` but accepts only location)
        * end (informs that the script is finished)
    - You must end the script with end() or openWindow().
    - The script will be executed as it is in the client browser. To make sure that the script works, check it on
      https://caniuse.com.
 * For the info link type, provide valid HTML. When users click on the link, they
   will see the information specified in HTML.

type.description: A type of the application login link.

content.description: Login link content. Valid values depend on the selected link type.

is_default.description: If true, the Application is default.

is_visible.description: If true, the Application is visible.

is_buildin.description:
If true, the application is built in and cannot be deleted or edited
(except the `is_visible` and `is_default` properties).

vs_disk_driver.description: Defines the disk driver for an OS image version. Will set the settings for the VM.

vs_firmware.description: Defines the firmware for an OS image version. Will set the settings for the VM.

password.description: User password. It must contain a mix of upper and lower case letters, as well as digits.

language_id.description: The ID of the interface language.

password.description: User password. It must contain a mix of upper and lower case letters, as well as digits.

code.description: The code from the authenticator application or recovery code.

full_backup_count.description: The number of full server backups.

deleted_at.description: The date the server was deleted at.

created_at.description: The date the backup was created.

backup_fail_reason.description: A reason why the backup could not be created.

create.description: The number of concurrent operations to create backups.

restore.description: The number of concurrent operations to restore backups.

compute_resources.description: An array of compute resources' IDs the backup node will be attached to.

compute_resources_count.description: A number of compute resources attached to the backup node

backups_count.description: A number of backups stored in the backup node

total_backups_size.description: The total size of backups stored in the backup node

use "lkey" to authenticate via RSA private key.

agent_port.description: The agent port for Computer resource installation, must be opened

locations.description: Array of location ids to which this compute resource should be attached.

ip_blocks.description: Array of ip block ids which should be used for attaching ip address to servers on this CR.

is_locked.description: Users can't create servers using a locked compute resource.

is_in_maintenance.description: The compute resource is under maintenance.

vm.description: The limit on a number servers that can be created from the compute resource

vcpu.description: The limit on a number of virtual CPU cores

vs_disk_cache_mode.description: Defines disk cache mode for new KVM servers. If not specified then global setting is applied.

ip_for_vpc_network.description: The IP address that is required for VPC networks.

ComputeResourceVirtualizationTypes.description: An array of enabled virtualization types.

cache_path.description: The cache path for temporary OS images

iso_path.description: The iso path for server iso images

backup_tmp_path.description: The temp directory for server images before upload

balance_strategy.description:
Storage balancing algorithm. Defines how the compute resource's storage is chosen for new servers
deployed within the same storage type.

force.description: The 'true' value triggers the force action.

application_data.description: The data of the application that will be installed on the server.

ssh_keys.description: An array of SSH keys IDs. The SSH keys will be added to the server.

fqdns.description: Server's FQDN list. Invalid FQDNs will be ignored.

is_disaster_recovery_enabled.description: Enable disaster recovery for this server.

vms_count.description: A number of servers created from the compute resource

is_in_maintenance.description: The compute resource is under maintenance.

kvm.description: If true, the compute resource supports KVM virtualization.

vz.description: If true, the compute resource supports VZ virtualization.

is_management_node.description: If true, the compute resource is the management node.

is_mem_balloon_free_page_reporting_suppo.description: If true, the compute resource supports the 'free page reporting' memory ballon parameter.

is_virtio_discard_supported.description: If true, the compute resource supports discard for virtio-blk devices.

start_action.description: Whether the VM should be started or stopped

cache_path.description: The cache path for temporary OS images

iso_path.description: The path for server cloud init iso images

backup_tmp_path.description: The temp directory for backups before upload to backup node

balance_strategy.description:
Storage balancing algorithm. Defines how the compute resource's storage is chosen for new servers
deployed within the same storage type.

vs_disk_cache_mode.description: Defines disk cache mode for new KVM servers. If not specified then global setting is applied.

server_count.description: The number of servers deployed on the compute resource

cpu.description: The number of CPUs allocated to the compute resource's servers

ram.description: The amount of memory in bytes allocated to the compute resource's servers

disk.description: The amount of storage in GiB allocated to the compute resource's servers

is_in_maintenance.description: The compute resource is under maintenance.

DiskDriver.description: Should be synced with enum `DiskDriver` in `frontend/src/common/api/resources/ComputeResourceVm/model.ts`.

delayed.description: If false, task will be dispatched immediately.

If false, task will be dispatched immediately.

force.description: The 'true' value triggers the force action.

project.description: The ID of a project under which the server will be created.

application.description: The ID of the application that will be installed on the server.

application_data.description: The data of the application that will be installed on the server.

plan.description: The ID of a plan according to which the server will be created.

location.description: The ID of a location within which the server will be created.

os.description: The ID of an OS image that will be installed on the server.

ssh_keys.description: An array of SSH keys IDs. The SSH keys will be added to the server.

user_data.description:
Additional users' data.
            The commands you specify in the data will be run at the first server boot.
user_data.example:
#cloud-config
            runcmd:
              - echo 'echo Hello from User Data' > /root/hello-world-user-data.sh
              - [ chmod, +x, /root/hello-world-user-data.sh ]

fqdns.description: Server's FQDN list. Invalid FQDNs will be ignored.

ip_types.description:
The array of IP address types.
            If the field is not present in the request, all types will be selected.

primary_ip.description: Primary IP. Can be IPv4 or IPv6.

vpc_networks.description: An array of VPC network IDs. The server will be attached to these VPC networks.

mac_address.description:
MAC address for Primary Network Interface. Will only be processed if the user has
            permissions to manage servers

is_disaster_recovery_enabled.description: Enable disaster recovery for this server.

enabled.description: If true, backups are enabled for server.

time.description: The backup start time in the UTC format.

days.description:
Days when backups are created. You can specify the following values:
                    Monthly: numbers between 1 and 31, where 1 is the first day of the month,
                    2 is the second day of the month, and so on.
                    Weekly: numbers between 1 and 7, where 1 is for Monday, 2 is for Tuesday, and so on.
                    Daily: no values are necessary.

CustomPlan.description:
If passed then hidden custom plan for the server will be created.
    All custom plan properties are optional if plan is passed and they overrides plan properties.

storage_type.description: Storage type for saving data, fb - file-based or lvm - thin LVM

image_format.description: For fb storage type is qcow2 and raw, for lvm storages only raw is allowed

is_editable.description: Allow users to change this setting per virtual server
Allow users to change this setting per virtual server

ppp.description: Point-to-Point Protocol (available only for VZ plans).

user_id.description: User ID that will own the server

#cloud-config
runcmd:
  - echo 'echo Hello from User Data' > /root/hello-world-user-data.sh
  - [ chmod, +x, /root/hello-world-user-data.sh ]

interval.description: Remove servers with time interval in minutes

scheduled_time.description: The update start time of the application (in the UTC format).

server_creation.description: The server creation settings in the User Area.

is_enabled.description: If true, backups are enabled for the management node.

backup_node_id.description: The ID of the backup node that stores the management node backups.

time.description: The backup start time in the UTC format.

hour.description: No value is necessary when hourly type is used.

days.description:
Days when backups are created. You can specify the following values:
Monthly: numbers between 1 and 31, where 1 is the first day of the month, 2 is the second day of the month, and so on.
Weekly: numbers between 1 and 7, where 1 is for Monday, 2 is for Tuesday, and so on.
Daily: no values are necessary.
Hourly: no values are necessary.

is_enabled.description: If true, backups are enabled for servers.

compute_resources.description: List of the compute resources whose servers will be backed up.

excluded_servers.description: List of the excluded servers that will not be backed up.

Days when backups are created. You can specify the following values:
Monthly: numbers between 1 and 31, where 1 is the first day of the month, 2 is the second day of the month, and so on.
Weekly: numbers between 1 and 7, where 1 is for Monday, 2 is for Tuesday, and so on.
Daily: no values are necessary.

incremental_backups_limit.description: The maximum number of incremental backups from one full backup.

cr_limit.description: The list of compute resource types exceeding the limit on the number of created compute resources.

vs_per_cr_limit.description: The list of compute resource types exceeding the limit on the number of created virtual servers.

crs_on_management_node.description: The list of compute resources installed on the management server.

is_primary.description: Whether the disk is a primary one.

output.description: Additional information in the response (if any)

is_retryable.description: If true, the task can be retried. Only tasks with the status 'failed' are retryable.

is_cancelable.description: If true, the task can be canceled.

compute_resource_vm_uuid.description: The virtual server attached to the task.

additional_ips.description: The number of additional IPv4 addresses.

iso_images_size.description: The total size of all user's ISO images.

api_key.description: To send API requests, pass `Authorization: Bearer $API_TOKEN` in HTTP headers.
api_key.name: authorization

tags.name: User Auth
tags.description:
To start working with the API, you must have a registered user.
You can register a user in the interface or via the API (the request is below).
Once you have registered a user, you can provide the user's credentials to create an API token.

tags.name: Projects
tags.description:
Projects are serve two purposes:
* They group servers. Each server is created under a particular project.
* They allow you to collaborate with other users and work together on the same project.
Users invited to the project (we call them project members) have the same permissions as the project owner:
they can create, delete, and manage servers under the project.

tags.name: Project Members
tags.description:
Project members are other service users that you invited to your project.
They have the same permissions as the project owner: they can create, delete, and manage servers under the project.

tags.name: Project Servers
tags.description:
Servers are virtual machines that you deploy. Each server is created under a particular project. This
section shows how to do the following:
* Retrieve a list of all servers created under a particular project.
* Create a server with the desired server’s settings (a compute resource, a plan, an OS, and so on).

tags.name: Project SSH Keys
tags.description: Project SSH keys are SSH keys linked to projects.

tags.name: Servers
tags.description:
Servers are virtual machines that you deploy. Use the `/servers` endpoint to do the following:
* See information about a particular server.
* Create, update, and delete servers.
* See a list of server snapshots and create server snapshots.

tags.name: Server Actions
tags.description:
Servers are virtual machines that you deploy. You can start, stop, and restart servers and also
connect to a server VNC console.

tags.name: Snapshots
tags.description:
A snapshot is a copy of a server at a particular point in time. If anything goes wrong with the server
(for example, after software update), you can return to the successful server configuration by restoring a snapshot.

tags.name: Locations
tags.description:
Locations, or locations as we call them in the interface
, inform where nodes are geographically
placed. To decrease network latency, choose a location closest to your actual geographical location when you create a
server.

tags.name: OS Images
tags.description: Operating systems that can be installed on your server.

tags.name: Plans
tags.description:
Plans, or packages as we call them in the user interface, are templates according to which
you create servers. Plans define how much compute resources (CPU, RAM, and disk space) a server can have and what price
 you pay for the server.

tags.name: Account
tags.description:
* See and update information about your account.
* See and delete your notifications.

tags.name: SshKeys
tags.description: See your existing SSH keys and add new ones.

tags.name: API Tokens
tags.description:
API tokens are necessary to send and authenticate your API requests. You can see, create, and delete
your API tokens.

tags.name: Compute Resource Actions
tags.description:
You can perform the following actions to a compute resource:
* See all network interfaces and configure network.
* See system metrics (name, ID, and so on) and existing storages.

tags.name: Compute Resources
tags.description:
Compute resources are physical servers (nodes) connected to the main physical server. They provide
resources (CPU, RAM, and disk space) the customers consume to deploy their own servers.

tags.name: Compute Resource Servers
tags.description: See existing servers or create new ones under a specific compute resource.

tags.name: Server Batch Actions
tags.description: Start, restart, stop, or delete multiple servers with one API request.

tags.name: IP
tags.description:
Free up one or more reserved IP addresses. They will be again available to be assigned to newly
created servers.

tags.name: IP Blocks
tags.description:
An IP block is a range of IP addresses from which each created server receives its IP address.
 You can reserve an IP address inside an IP block to prevent the IP address from being assigned to a created server.

tags.name: Limit Groups
tags.description:
A limit group limits the compute resources consumption. You can assign the limit group to one or more
users to prevent the resources overuse.

tags.name: Notifications
tags.description: Delete your notifications by their IDs.

tags.name: Permissions
tags.description:
Users can have various permissions (to manage IP blocks, to manage plans, and so on).
To grant specific permissions to users, first create sets of permissions, which are called *roles*, and then assign the
roles to users.

tags.name: Roles
tags.description:
Roles are sets of permissions (to manage IP blocks, to manage plans, and so on) that you assign to
users.

tags.name: Settings
tags.description:
See and update the general settings of your application (the update settings, custom colors, a
balancing algorithm, and so on).

tags.name: SSH Keys
tags.description: See, create, and delete your SSH keys and those that belong to other users.

tags.name: Storage Types
tags.description:
Storage virtualization types (File Based, LVM, and ThinLVM) define how disk is partitioned and data is
* packed.

tags.name: Tasks
tags.description:
Tasks are certain actions in the application that take some time to be completed (for example,
creating a compute resource, updating the application, creating a server, and so on).

tags.name: Updates
tags.description: See information about updates and update the application if updates are available.

tags.name: Usage
tags.description: Shows the information about server uptime in tokens for the specific month.

tags.name: Users
tags.description: You can create users with various roles (sets of permissions).

tags.name: Backups
tags.description: Server backups.

tags.name: Backup Nodes
tags.description: Backup nodes.

tags.name: Management Node Backups
tags.description: Management node backups.

tags.name: Cluster Imports
tags.description: Cluster Imports.

tags.name: ReverseDns
tags.description: Reverse DNS.

tags.name: Activity Logs
tags.description: Activity Logs.

tags.name: Servers Migration
tags.description: Servers Migration.

tags.name: ISO Images
tags.description:
A custom ISO image can contain an operating system of one's choice.
These images can be then offered to customers.

tags.name: Storage tag
tags.description:
A storage tag is used to mark a CR storage.
This tag can be further used for creating a virtual server on a storage of a particular type.

tags.name: Offers
tags.description:
Offers define the price for the server's additional options,
such as additional disks and a type of the primary disk.

tags.name: Server Disks
tags.description: Primary and additional disks of a server.

tags.name: VPC Networks
tags.description:
Virtual Private Cloud Network provide a more secure connection between resources because
the network is inaccessible from the public internet and other VPC networks.

tags.name: Tags
tags.description: Key-value tags that can be attached to entities.
